original_glossary_extracted: Letter of credit  Form of external credit enhancement whereby a financial institution provides the issuer with a credit line to reimburse any cash flow shortfalls from the assets backing the issue.
definition_or_explanation: Form of external credit enhancement whereby a financial institution provides the issuer with a credit line to reimburse any cash flow shortfalls from the assets backing the issue.

original_glossary_extracted: Level of significance  The probability of a Type I error in testing a hypothesis.
definition_or_explanation: The probability of a Type I error in testing a hypothesis.

original_glossary_extracted: Leverage  In the context of corporate finance, leverage refers to the use of fixed costs within a company's cost structure. Fixed costs that are operating costs (such as depreciation or rent) create operating leverage. Fixed costs that are financial costs (such as interest expense) create financial leverage.
definition_or_explanation: In the context of corporate finance, leverage refers to the use of fixed costs within a company's cost structure. Fixed costs that are operating costs (such as depreciation or rent) create operating leverage. Fixed costs that are financial costs (such as interest expense) create financial leverage.

original_glossary_extracted: Leveraged buyout  (LBO) A transaction whereby the target company management team converts the target to a pri-vately held company by using heavy borrowing to finance the purchase of the target company's outstanding shares.
definition_or_explanation: A transaction whereby the target company management team converts the target to a pri-vately held company by using heavy borrowing to finance the purchase of the target company's outstanding shares.

original_glossary_extracted: Liabilities  Present obligations of an enterprise arising from past events, the settlement of which is expected to result in an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits; creditors' claims on the resources of a company.
definition_or_explanation: Present obligations of an enterprise arising from past events, the settlement of which is expected to result in an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits; creditors' claims on the resources of a company.

original_glossary_extracted: Life-cycle stage  The stage of the life cycle: embryonic, growth, shakeout, mature, declining.
definition_or_explanation: The stage of the life cycle: embryonic, growth, shakeout, mature, declining.

original_glossary_extracted: LIFO layer liquidation  With respect to the application of the LIFO inventory method, the liquidation of old, relatively low-priced inventory; happens when the volume of sales rises above the volume of recent purchases so that some sales are made from relatively old, low-priced inventory. Also called LIFO liquidation.
definition_or_explanation: With respect to the application of the LIFO inventory method, the liquidation of old, relatively low-priced inventory; happens when the volume of sales rises above the volume of recent purchases so that some sales are made from relatively old, low-priced inventory. Also called LIFO liquidation.

original_glossary_extracted: LIFO method  The last in, first out, method of accounting for inventory, which matches sales against the costs of items of inventory in the reverse order the items were placed in inventory (i.e., inventory produced or acquired last are assumed to be sold first).
definition_or_explanation: The last in, first out, method of accounting for inventory, which matches sales against the costs of items of inventory in the reverse order the items were placed in inventory (i.e., inventory produced or acquired last are assumed to be sold first).

original_glossary_extracted: LIFO reserve  The difference between the reported LIFO inven-tory carrying amount and the inventory amount that would have been reported if the FIFO method had been used (in other words, the FIFO inventory value less the LIFO inventory value).
definition_or_explanation: The difference between the reported LIFO inven-tory carrying amount and the inventory amount that would have been reported if the FIFO method had been used (in other words, the FIFO inventory value less the LIFO inventory value).

original_glossary_extracted: Likelihood  The probability of an observation, given a partic-ular set of conditions.
definition_or_explanation: The probability of an observation, given a partic-ular set of conditions.

original_glossary_extracted: Limit down  A limit move in the futures market in which the price at which a transaction would be made is at or below the lower limit.
definition_or_explanation: A limit move in the futures market in which the price at which a transaction would be made is at or below the lower limit.

original_glossary_extracted: Limit order  Instructions to a broker or exchange to obtain the best price immediately available when filling an order, but in no event accept a price higher than a specified (limit) price when buying or accept a price lower than a specified (limit) price when selling.
definition_or_explanation: Instructions to a broker or exchange to obtain the best price immediately available when filling an order, but in no event accept a price higher than a specified (limit) price when buying or accept a price lower than a specified (limit) price when selling.

original_glossary_extracted: Limit order book  The book or list of limit orders to buy and sell that pertains to a security.
definition_or_explanation: The book or list of limit orders to buy and sell that pertains to a security.

original_glossary_extracted: Limit up  A limit move in the futures market in which the price at which a transaction would be made is at or above the upper limit.
definition_or_explanation: A limit move in the futures market in which the price at which a transaction would be made is at or above the upper limit.

original_glossary_extracted: Limitations on liens  Meant to put limits on how much secured debt an issuer can have.
definition_or_explanation: Meant to put limits on how much secured debt an issuer can have.

original_glossary_extracted: Limited partners  Partners with limited liability. Limited part-nerships in hedge and private equity funds are typically restricted to investors who are expected to understand and to be able to assume the risks associated with the investments.
definition_or_explanation: Partners with limited liability. Limited part-nerships in hedge and private equity funds are typically restricted to investors who are expected to understand and to be able to assume the risks associated with the investments.

original_glossary_extracted: Line chart  In technical analysis, a plot of price data, typically closing prices, with a line connecting the points.
definition_or_explanation: In technical analysis, a plot of price data, typically closing prices, with a line connecting the points.

original_glossary_extracted: Linear interpolation  The estimation of an unknown value on the basis of two known values that bracket it, using a straight line between the two known values.
definition_or_explanation: The estimation of an unknown value on the basis of two known values that bracket it, using a straight line between the two known values.

original_glossary_extracted: Linear scale  A scale in which equal distances correspond to equal absolute amounts. Also called arithmetic scale.
definition_or_explanation: A scale in which equal distances correspond to equal absolute amounts. Also called arithmetic scale.

original_glossary_extracted: Linker  See inflation-linked bond.
definition_or_explanation: See inflation-linked bond.

original_glossary_extracted: Liquid market  Said of a market in which traders can buy or sell with low total transaction costs when they want to trade.
definition_or_explanation: Said of a market in which traders can buy or sell with low total transaction costs when they want to trade.

original_glossary_extracted: Liquidation  To sell the assets of a company, division, or subsidiary piecemeal, typically because of bankruptcy; the form of bankruptcy that allows for the orderly satisfaction of creditors' claims after which the company ceases to exist.
definition_or_explanation: To sell the assets of a company, division, or subsidiary piecemeal, typically because of bankruptcy; the form of bankruptcy that allows for the orderly satisfaction of creditors' claims after which the company ceases to exist.

original_glossary_extracted: Liquidity  The ability to purchase or sell an asset quickly and easily at a price close to fair market value. The ability to meet short-term obligations using assets that are the most readily converted into cash.
definition_or_explanation: The ability to purchase or sell an asset quickly and easily at a price close to fair market value. The ability to meet short-term obligations using assets that are the most readily converted into cash.

original_glossary_extracted: Liquidity premium  An extra return that compensates inves-tors for the risk of loss relative to an investment's fair value if the investment needs to be converted to cash quickly.
definition_or_explanation: An extra return that compensates inves-tors for the risk of loss relative to an investment's fair value if the investment needs to be converted to cash quickly.

original_glossary_extracted: Liquidity ratios  Financial ratios measuring the company's ability to meet its short-term obligations.
definition_or_explanation: Financial ratios measuring the company's ability to meet its short-term obligations.

original_glossary_extracted: Liquidity risk  The risk that a financial instrument cannot be purchased or sold without a significant concession in price due to the size of the market.
definition_or_explanation: The risk that a financial instrument cannot be purchased or sold without a significant concession in price due to the size of the market.

original_glossary_extracted: Liquidity trap  A condition in which the demand for money becomes infinitely elastic (horizontal demand curve) so that injections of money into the economy will not lower interest rates or affect real activity.
definition_or_explanation: A condition in which the demand for money becomes infinitely elastic (horizontal demand curve) so that injections of money into the economy will not lower interest rates or affect real activity.

original_glossary_extracted: Load fund  A mutual fund in which, in addition to the annual fee, a percentage fee is charged to invest in the fund and/or for redemptions from the fund.
definition_or_explanation: A mutual fund in which, in addition to the annual fee, a percentage fee is charged to invest in the fund and/or for redemptions from the fund.

original_glossary_extracted: Loan-to-value ratio  The ratio of a property's purchase price to the amount of its mortgage.
definition_or_explanation: The ratio of a property's purchase price to the amount of its mortgage.

original_glossary_extracted: Lockbox system  A payment system in which customer pay-ments are mailed to a post office box and the banking institution retrieves and deposits these payments several times a day, enabling the company to have use of the fund sooner than in a centralized system in which customer payments are sent to the company.
definition_or_explanation: A payment system in which customer pay-ments are mailed to a post office box and the banking institution retrieves and deposits these payments several times a day, enabling the company to have use of the fund sooner than in a centralized system in which customer payments are sent to the company.

original_glossary_extracted: Locked limit  A condition in the futures markets in which a transaction cannot take place because the price would be beyond the limits.
definition_or_explanation: A condition in the futures markets in which a transaction cannot take place because the price would be beyond the limits.

original_glossary_extracted: Lockup period  The minimum period before investors are allowed to make withdrawals or redeem shares from a fund.
definition_or_explanation: The minimum period before investors are allowed to make withdrawals or redeem shares from a fund.

original_glossary_extracted: Logarithmic scale  A scale in which equal distances represent equal proportional changes in the underlying quantity.
definition_or_explanation: A scale in which equal distances represent equal proportional changes in the underlying quantity.

original_glossary_extracted: London interbank offered rate (Libor)  Collective name for multiple rates at which a select set of banks believe they could borrow unsecured funds from other banks in the London interbank market for different currencies and different borrowing periods ranging from overnight to one year.
definition_or_explanation: Collective name for multiple rates at which a select set of banks believe they could borrow unsecured funds from other banks in the London interbank market for different currencies and different borrowing periods ranging from overnight to one year.

original_glossary_extracted: Long  The buyer of a derivative contract. Also refers to the position of owning a derivative.
definition_or_explanation: The buyer of a derivative contract. Also refers to the position of owning a derivative.

original_glossary_extracted: Long-lived assets  Assets that are expected to provide eco-nomic benefits over a future period of time, typically greater than one year. Also called long-term assets.
definition_or_explanation: Assets that are expected to provide eco-nomic benefits over a future period of time, typically greater than one year. Also called long-term assets.

original_glossary_extracted: Long position  A position in an asset or contract in which one owns the asset or has an exercisable right under the contract.
definition_or_explanation: A position in an asset or contract in which one owns the asset or has an exercisable right under the contract.

original_glossary_extracted: Long-run average total cost  The curve describing average total cost when no costs are considered fixed.
definition_or_explanation: The curve describing average total cost when no costs are considered fixed.

original_glossary_extracted: Long-term contract  A contract that spans a number of accounting periods.
definition_or_explanation: A contract that spans a number of accounting periods.

original_glossary_extracted: Longitudinal data  Observations on characteristic(s) of the same observational unit through time.
definition_or_explanation: Observations on characteristic(s) of the same observational unit through time.

original_glossary_extracted: Look-ahead bias  A bias caused by using information that was unavailable on the test date.
definition_or_explanation: A bias caused by using information that was unavailable on the test date.

original_glossary_extracted: Loss aversion  The tendency of people to dislike losses more than they like comparable gains.
definition_or_explanation: The tendency of people to dislike losses more than they like comparable gains.

original_glossary_extracted: Loss severity  Portion of a bond's value (including unpaid interest) an investor loses in the event of default.
definition_or_explanation: Portion of a bond's value (including unpaid interest) an investor loses in the event of default.

original_glossary_extracted: Losses  Asset outflows not directly related to the ordinary activities of the business.
definition_or_explanation: Asset outflows not directly related to the ordinary activities of the business.

original_glossary_extracted: Lower bound  The lowest possible value of an option.
definition_or_explanation: The lowest possible value of an option.

original_glossary_extracted: M2  A measure of what a portfolio would have returned if it had taken on the same total risk as the market index.
definition_or_explanation: A measure of what a portfolio would have returned if it had taken on the same total risk as the market index.

original_glossary_extracted: Macaulay duration  The approximate amount of time a bond would have to be held for the market discount rate at pur-chase to be realized if there is a single change in interest rate. It indicates the point in time when the coupon rein-vestment and price effects of a change in yield-to-maturity offset each other.
definition_or_explanation: The approximate amount of time a bond would have to be held for the market discount rate at pur-chase to be realized if there is a single change in interest rate. It indicates the point in time when the coupon rein-vestment and price effects of a change in yield-to-maturity offset each other.

original_glossary_extracted: Machine learning  Diverse approaches by which computers are programmed to improve performance in specified tasks with experience.
definition_or_explanation: Diverse approaches by which computers are programmed to improve performance in specified tasks with experience.

original_glossary_extracted: Macroeconomics  The branch of economics that deals with aggregate economic quantities, such as national output and national income.
definition_or_explanation: The branch of economics that deals with aggregate economic quantities, such as national output and national income.

original_glossary_extracted: Maintenance covenants  Covenants in bank loan agreements that require the borrower to satisfy certain financial ratio tests while the loan is outstanding.
definition_or_explanation: Covenants in bank loan agreements that require the borrower to satisfy certain financial ratio tests while the loan is outstanding.

original_glossary_extracted: Maintenance margin  The minimum amount that is required by a futures clearinghouse to maintain a margin account and to protect against default. Participants whose margin balances drop below the required maintenance margin must replenish their accounts.
definition_or_explanation: The minimum amount that is required by a futures clearinghouse to maintain a margin account and to protect against default. Participants whose margin balances drop below the required maintenance margin must replenish their accounts.

original_glossary_extracted: Maintenance margin requirement  The margin requirement on any day other than the first day of a transaction.
definition_or_explanation: The margin requirement on any day other than the first day of a transaction.

original_glossary_extracted: Management buy-ins  Leveraged buyout in which the current management team is being replaced and the acquiring team will be involved in managing the company.
definition_or_explanation: Leveraged buyout in which the current management team is being replaced and the acquiring team will be involved in managing the company.

original_glossary_extracted: Management buyout  (MBO) A leveraged buyout event in which a group of investors consisting primarily of the com-pany's existing management purchase at least controlling interest of its outstanding shares. They may purchase all shares and take the company private.
definition_or_explanation: A leveraged buyout event in which a group of investors consisting primarily of the com-pany's existing management purchase at least controlling interest of its outstanding shares. They may purchase all shares and take the company private.

original_glossary_extracted: Management fee  A fee based on assets under management or committed capital, as applicable, also called a base fee.
definition_or_explanation: A fee based on assets under management or committed capital, as applicable, also called a base fee.

original_glossary_extracted: Manufacturing resource planning (MRP)  The incorporation of production planning into inventory management. A MRP analysis provides both a materials acquisition sched-ule and a production schedule.
definition_or_explanation: The incorporation of production planning into inventory management. A MRP analysis provides both a materials acquisition sched-ule and a production schedule.

original_glossary_extracted: Margin  The amount of money that a trader deposits in a margin account. The term is derived from the stock mar-ket practice in which an investor borrows a portion of the money required to purchase a certain amount of stock. In futures markets, there is no borrowing so the margin is more of a down payment or performance bond.
definition_or_explanation: The amount of money that a trader deposits in a margin account. The term is derived from the stock mar-ket practice in which an investor borrows a portion of the money required to purchase a certain amount of stock. In futures markets, there is no borrowing so the margin is more of a down payment or performance bond.

original_glossary_extracted: Margin bond  A cash deposit required by the clearinghouse from the participants to a contract to provide a credit guarantee. Also called a performance bond.
definition_or_explanation: A cash deposit required by the clearinghouse from the participants to a contract to provide a credit guarantee. Also called a performance bond.

original_glossary_extracted: Margin call  A request for the short to deposit additional funds to bring their balance up to the initial margin.
definition_or_explanation: A request for the short to deposit additional funds to bring their balance up to the initial margin.

original_glossary_extracted: Margin loan  Money borrowed from a broker to purchase securities.
definition_or_explanation: Money borrowed from a broker to purchase securities.

original_glossary_extracted: Marginal cost  The cost of producing an additional unit of a good.
definition_or_explanation: The cost of producing an additional unit of a good.

original_glossary_extracted: Marginal probability  The probability of an event not condi-tioned on another event.
definition_or_explanation: The probability of an event not condi-tioned on another event.

original_glossary_extracted: Marginal product  Measures the productivity of each unit of input and is calculated by taking the difference in total product from adding another unit of input (assuming other resource quantities are held constant).
definition_or_explanation: Measures the productivity of each unit of input and is calculated by taking the difference in total product from adding another unit of input (assuming other resource quantities are held constant).

original_glossary_extracted: Marginal propensity to consume  The proportion of an addi-tional unit of disposable income that is consumed or spent; the change in consumption for a small change in income.
definition_or_explanation: The proportion of an addi-tional unit of disposable income that is consumed or spent; the change in consumption for a small change in income.

original_glossary_extracted: Marginal propensity to save  The proportion of an additional unit of disposable income that is saved (not spent).
definition_or_explanation: The proportion of an additional unit of disposable income that is saved (not spent).

original_glossary_extracted: Marginal revenue  The change in total revenue divided by the change in quantity sold; simply, the additional revenue from selling one more unit.
definition_or_explanation: The change in total revenue divided by the change in quantity sold; simply, the additional revenue from selling one more unit.

original_glossary_extracted: Marginal value curve  A curve describing the highest price consumers are willing to pay for each additional unit of a good.
definition_or_explanation: A curve describing the highest price consumers are willing to pay for each additional unit of a good.

original_glossary_extracted: Mark to market  The revaluation of a financial asset or liability to its current market value or fair value.
definition_or_explanation: The revaluation of a financial asset or liability to its current market value or fair value.

original_glossary_extracted: Market  A means of bringing buyers and sellers together to exchange goods and services.
definition_or_explanation: A means of bringing buyers and sellers together to exchange goods and services.

original_glossary_extracted: Market anomaly  Change in the price or return of a security that cannot directly be linked to current relevant infor-mation known in the market or to the release of new information into the market.
definition_or_explanation: Change in the price or return of a security that cannot directly be linked to current relevant infor-mation known in the market or to the release of new information into the market.

original_glossary_extracted: Market bid-ask spread  The difference between the best bid and the best offer.
definition_or_explanation: The difference between the best bid and the best offer.

original_glossary_extracted: Market-capitalization weighting  An index weighting method in which the weight assigned to each constituent security is determined by dividing its market capitalization by the total market capitalization (sum of the market capitalization) of all securities in the index. Also called value weighting.
definition_or_explanation: An index weighting method in which the weight assigned to each constituent security is determined by dividing its market capitalization by the total market capitalization (sum of the market capitalization) of all securities in the index. Also called value weighting.

original_glossary_extracted: Market discount rate  The rate of return required by investors given the risk of the investment in a bond; also called the required yield or the required rate of return.
definition_or_explanation: The rate of return required by investors given the risk of the investment in a bond; also called the required yield or the required rate of return.

original_glossary_extracted: Market float  The number of shares that are available to the investing public.
definition_or_explanation: The number of shares that are available to the investing public.

original_glossary_extracted: Market liquidity risk  The risk that the price at which investors can actually transact-buying or selling-may differ from the price indicated in the market.
definition_or_explanation: The risk that the price at which investors can actually transact-buying or selling-may differ from the price indicated in the market.

original_glossary_extracted: Market model  A regression equation that specifies a linear relationship between the return on a security (or portfolio) and the return on a broad market index.
definition_or_explanation: A regression equation that specifies a linear relationship between the return on a security (or portfolio) and the return on a broad market index.

original_glossary_extracted: Market multiple models  Valuation models based on share price multiples or enterprise value multiples.
definition_or_explanation: Valuation models based on share price multiples or enterprise value multiples.

original_glossary_extracted: Market-on-close  An execution instruction specifying that an order can only be filled at the close of trading.
definition_or_explanation: An execution instruction specifying that an order can only be filled at the close of trading.

original_glossary_extracted: Market order  Instructions to a broker or exchange to obtain the best price immediately available when filling an order.
definition_or_explanation: Instructions to a broker or exchange to obtain the best price immediately available when filling an order.

original_glossary_extracted: Market-oriented investors  With reference to equity investors, investors whose investment disciplines cannot be clearly categorized as value or growth.
definition_or_explanation: With reference to equity investors, investors whose investment disciplines cannot be clearly categorized as value or growth.

original_glossary_extracted: Market rate of interest  The rate demanded by purchases of bonds, given the risks associated with future cash payment obligations of the particular bond issue.
definition_or_explanation: The rate demanded by purchases of bonds, given the risks associated with future cash payment obligations of the particular bond issue.

original_glossary_extracted: Market risk  The risk that arises from movements in interest rates, stock prices, exchange rates, and commodity prices.
definition_or_explanation: The risk that arises from movements in interest rates, stock prices, exchange rates, and commodity prices.

original_glossary_extracted: Market value  The price at which an asset or security can currently be bought or sold in an open market.
definition_or_explanation: The price at which an asset or security can currently be bought or sold in an open market.

original_glossary_extracted: Marketable limit order  A buy limit order in which the limit price is placed above the best offer, or a sell limit order in which the limit price is placed below the best bid. Such orders generally will partially or completely fill right away.
definition_or_explanation: A buy limit order in which the limit price is placed above the best offer, or a sell limit order in which the limit price is placed below the best bid. Such orders generally will partially or completely fill right away.

original_glossary_extracted: Markowitz efficient frontier  The graph of the set of portfolios offering the maximum expected return for their level of risk (standard deviation of return).
definition_or_explanation: The graph of the set of portfolios offering the maximum expected return for their level of risk (standard deviation of return).

original_glossary_extracted: Matching principle  The accounting principle that expenses should be recognized when the associated revenue is recognized.
definition_or_explanation: The accounting principle that expenses should be recognized when the associated revenue is recognized.

original_glossary_extracted: Matching strategy  An active investment strategy that includes intentional matching of the timing of cash outflows with investment maturities.
definition_or_explanation: An active investment strategy that includes intentional matching of the timing of cash outflows with investment maturities.

original_glossary_extracted: Matrix pricing  Process of estimating the market discount rate and price of a bond based on the quoted or flat prices of more frequently traded comparable bonds.
definition_or_explanation: Process of estimating the market discount rate and price of a bond based on the quoted or flat prices of more frequently traded comparable bonds.

original_glossary_extracted: Maturity premium  An extra return that compensates investors for the increased sensitivity of the market value of debt to a change in market interest rates as maturity is extended.
definition_or_explanation: An extra return that compensates investors for the increased sensitivity of the market value of debt to a change in market interest rates as maturity is extended.

original_glossary_extracted: Maturity structure  A factor explaining the differences in yields on similar bonds; also called term structure.
definition_or_explanation: A factor explaining the differences in yields on similar bonds; also called term structure.

original_glossary_extracted: Mean absolute deviation  With reference to a sample, the mean of the absolute values of deviations from the sample mean.
definition_or_explanation: With reference to a sample, the mean of the absolute values of deviations from the sample mean.

original_glossary_extracted: Mean excess return  The average rate of return in excess of the risk-free rate.
definition_or_explanation: The average rate of return in excess of the risk-free rate.

original_glossary_extracted: Mean-variance analysis  An approach to portfolio analysis using expected means, variances, and covariances of asset returns.
definition_or_explanation: An approach to portfolio analysis using expected means, variances, and covariances of asset returns.

original_glossary_extracted: Measure of central tendency  A quantitative measure that specifies where data are centered.
definition_or_explanation: A quantitative measure that specifies where data are centered.

original_glossary_extracted: Measure of value  A standard for measuring value; a function of money.
definition_or_explanation: A standard for measuring value; a function of money.

original_glossary_extracted: Measurement scales  A scheme of measuring differences. The four types of measurement scales are nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio.
definition_or_explanation: A scheme of measuring differences. The four types of measurement scales are nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio.

original_glossary_extracted: Measures of location  A quantitative measure that describes the location or distribution of data; includes not only measures of central tendency but also other measures such as percentiles.
definition_or_explanation: A quantitative measure that describes the location or distribution of data; includes not only measures of central tendency but also other measures such as percentiles.

original_glossary_extracted: Median  The value of the middle item of a set of items that has been sorted into ascending or descending order; the 50th percentile.
definition_or_explanation: The value of the middle item of a set of items that has been sorted into ascending or descending order; the 50th percentile.

original_glossary_extracted: Medium of exchange  Any asset that can be used to purchase goods and services or to repay debts; a function of money.
definition_or_explanation: Any asset that can be used to purchase goods and services or to repay debts; a function of money.

original_glossary_extracted: Medium-term note  A corporate bond offered continuously to investors by an agent of the issuer, designed to fill the fund-ing gap between commercial paper and long-term bonds.
definition_or_explanation: A corporate bond offered continuously to investors by an agent of the issuer, designed to fill the fund-ing gap between commercial paper and long-term bonds.

original_glossary_extracted: Menu costs  A cost of inflation in which businesses constantly have to incur the costs of changing the advertised prices of their goods and services.
definition_or_explanation: A cost of inflation in which businesses constantly have to incur the costs of changing the advertised prices of their goods and services.

original_glossary_extracted: Mesokurtic  Describes a distribution with kurtosis identical to that of the normal distribution.
definition_or_explanation: Describes a distribution with kurtosis identical to that of the normal distribution.

original_glossary_extracted: Mezzanine financing  Debt or preferred shares with a rela-tionship to common equity resulting from a feature such as attached warrants or conversion options. Mezzanine financing is subordinate to both senior and high-yield debt. It is referred to as mezzanine because of its location on the balance sheet.
definition_or_explanation: Debt or preferred shares with a rela-tionship to common equity resulting from a feature such as attached warrants or conversion options. Mezzanine financing is subordinate to both senior and high-yield debt. It is referred to as mezzanine because of its location on the balance sheet.

original_glossary_extracted: Microeconomics  The branch of economics that deals with markets and decision making of individual economic units, including consumers and businesses.
definition_or_explanation: The branch of economics that deals with markets and decision making of individual economic units, including consumers and businesses.

original_glossary_extracted: Minimum efficient scale  The smallest output that a firm can produce such that its long-run average total cost is minimized.
definition_or_explanation: The smallest output that a firm can produce such that its long-run average total cost is minimized.

original_glossary_extracted: Minimum-variance portfolio  The portfolio with the minimum variance for each given level of expected return.
definition_or_explanation: The portfolio with the minimum variance for each given level of expected return.

original_glossary_extracted: Minority shareholders  A particular shareholder or block of shareholders holding a small proportion of a company's outstanding shares, resulting in a limited ability to exercise control in voting activities.
definition_or_explanation: A particular shareholder or block of shareholders holding a small proportion of a company's outstanding shares, resulting in a limited ability to exercise control in voting activities.

original_glossary_extracted: Minsky moment  Named for Hyman Minksy: A point in a business cycle when, after individuals become overextended in borrowing to finance speculative investments, people start realizing that something is likely to go wrong and a panic ensues leading to asset sell-offs.
definition_or_explanation: Named for Hyman Minksy: A point in a business cycle when, after individuals become overextended in borrowing to finance speculative investments, people start realizing that something is likely to go wrong and a panic ensues leading to asset sell-offs.

original_glossary_extracted: Mismatching strategy  An active investment strategy whereby the timing of cash outflows is not matched with investment maturities.
definition_or_explanation: An active investment strategy whereby the timing of cash outflows is not matched with investment maturities.

original_glossary_extracted: Modal interval  With reference to grouped data, the most frequently occurring interval.
definition_or_explanation: With reference to grouped data, the most frequently occurring interval.

original_glossary_extracted: Mode  The most frequently occurring value in a set of observations.
definition_or_explanation: The most frequently occurring value in a set of observations.

original_glossary_extracted: Modern portfolio theory  (MPT) The analysis of rational portfolio choices based on the efficient use of risk.
definition_or_explanation: The analysis of rational portfolio choices based on the efficient use of risk.

original_glossary_extracted: Modified duration  A measure of the percentage price change of a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity.
definition_or_explanation: A measure of the percentage price change of a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity.

original_glossary_extracted: Momentum oscillators  A graphical representation of market sentiment that is constructed from price data and calcu-lated so that it oscillates either between a high and a low or around some number.
definition_or_explanation: A graphical representation of market sentiment that is constructed from price data and calcu-lated so that it oscillates either between a high and a low or around some number.

original_glossary_extracted: Monetarists  Economists who believe that the rate of growth of the money supply is the primary determinant of the rate of inflation.
definition_or_explanation: Economists who believe that the rate of growth of the money supply is the primary determinant of the rate of inflation.

original_glossary_extracted: Monetary policy  Actions taken by a nation's central bank to affect aggregate output and prices through changes in bank reserves, reserve requirements, or its target interest rate.
definition_or_explanation: Actions taken by a nation's central bank to affect aggregate output and prices through changes in bank reserves, reserve requirements, or its target interest rate.

original_glossary_extracted: Monetary transmission mechanism  The process whereby a central bank's interest rate gets transmitted through the economy and ultimately affects the rate of increase of prices.
definition_or_explanation: The process whereby a central bank's interest rate gets transmitted through the economy and ultimately affects the rate of increase of prices.

original_glossary_extracted: Monetary union  An economic union in which the members adopt a common currency.
definition_or_explanation: An economic union in which the members adopt a common currency.

original_glossary_extracted: Money  A generally accepted medium of exchange and unit of account.
definition_or_explanation: A generally accepted medium of exchange and unit of account.

original_glossary_extracted: Money convexity  For a bond, the annual or approximate convexity multiplied by the full price.
definition_or_explanation: For a bond, the annual or approximate convexity multiplied by the full price.

original_glossary_extracted: Money creation  The process by which changes in bank reserves translate into changes in the money supply.
definition_or_explanation: The process by which changes in bank reserves translate into changes in the money supply.

original_glossary_extracted: Money duration  A measure of the price change in units of the currency in which the bond is denominated given a change in its yield-to-maturity.
definition_or_explanation: A measure of the price change in units of the currency in which the bond is denominated given a change in its yield-to-maturity.

original_glossary_extracted: Money market  The market for short-term debt instruments (one-year maturity or less).
definition_or_explanation: The market for short-term debt instruments (one-year maturity or less).

original_glossary_extracted: Money market securities  Fixed-income securities with matur-ities at issuance of one year or less.
definition_or_explanation: Fixed-income securities with matur-ities at issuance of one year or less.

original_glossary_extracted: Money market yield  A yield on a basis comparable to the quoted yield on an interest-bearing money market instru-ment that pays interest on a 360-day basis; the annualized holding period yield, assuming a 360-day year.
definition_or_explanation: A yield on a basis comparable to the quoted yield on an interest-bearing money market instru-ment that pays interest on a 360-day basis; the annualized holding period yield, assuming a 360-day year.

original_glossary_extracted: Money multiplier  Describes how a change in reserves is expected to affect the money supply; in its simplest form, 1 divided by the reserve requirement.
definition_or_explanation: Describes how a change in reserves is expected to affect the money supply; in its simplest form, 1 divided by the reserve requirement.

original_glossary_extracted: Money neutrality  The thesis that an increase in the money supply leads in the long-run to an increase in the price level, while leaving real variables like output and employ-ment unaffected.
definition_or_explanation: The thesis that an increase in the money supply leads in the long-run to an increase in the price level, while leaving real variables like output and employ-ment unaffected.

original_glossary_extracted: Money-weighted return  The internal rate of return on a portfolio, taking account of all cash flows.
definition_or_explanation: The internal rate of return on a portfolio, taking account of all cash flows.

original_glossary_extracted: Moneyness  The relationship between the price of the under-lying and an option's exercise price.
definition_or_explanation: The relationship between the price of the under-lying and an option's exercise price.

original_glossary_extracted: Monopolistic competition  Highly competitive form of imper-fect competition; the competitive characteristic is a notably large number of firms, while the monopoly aspect is the result of product differentiation.
definition_or_explanation: Highly competitive form of imper-fect competition; the competitive characteristic is a notably large number of firms, while the monopoly aspect is the result of product differentiation.

original_glossary_extracted: Monopoly  In pure monopoly markets, there are no substi-tutes for the given product or service. There is a single seller, which exercises considerable power over pricing and output decisions.
definition_or_explanation: In pure monopoly markets, there are no substi-tutes for the given product or service. There is a single seller, which exercises considerable power over pricing and output decisions.

original_glossary_extracted: Monte Carlo simulation  An approach to estimating a prob-ability distribution of outcomes to examine what might happen if particular risks are faced. This method is widely used in the sciences as well as in business to study a variety of problems.
definition_or_explanation: An approach to estimating a prob-ability distribution of outcomes to examine what might happen if particular risks are faced. This method is widely used in the sciences as well as in business to study a variety of problems.

original_glossary_extracted: Moral principles  Beliefs regarding what is good, acceptable, or obligatory behavior and what is bad, unacceptable, or forbidden behavior.
definition_or_explanation: Beliefs regarding what is good, acceptable, or obligatory behavior and what is bad, unacceptable, or forbidden behavior.

original_glossary_extracted: Mortgage-backed securities  Debt obligations that represent claims to the cash flows from pools of mortgage loans, most commonly on residential property.
definition_or_explanation: Debt obligations that represent claims to the cash flows from pools of mortgage loans, most commonly on residential property.

original_glossary_extracted: Mortgage loan  A loan secured by the collateral of some specified real estate property that obliges the borrower to make a predetermined series of payments to the lender.
definition_or_explanation: A loan secured by the collateral of some specified real estate property that obliges the borrower to make a predetermined series of payments to the lender.

original_glossary_extracted: Mortgage pass-through security  A security created when one or more holders of mortgages form a pool of mortgages and sell shares or participation certificates in the pool.
definition_or_explanation: A security created when one or more holders of mortgages form a pool of mortgages and sell shares or participation certificates in the pool.

original_glossary_extracted: Mortgage rate  The interest rate on a mortgage loan; also called contract rate or note rate.
definition_or_explanation: The interest rate on a mortgage loan; also called contract rate or note rate.

original_glossary_extracted: Moving average  The average of the closing price of a security over a specified number of periods. With each new period, the average is recalculated.Moving-average convergence/divergence oscilla-
definition_or_explanation: The average of the closing price of a security over a specified number of periods. With each new period, the average is recalculated.Moving-average convergence/divergence oscilla-

original_glossary_extracted: tor  (MACD) A momentum oscillator that is constructed based on the difference between short-term and long-term moving averages of a security's price.
definition_or_explanation: A momentum oscillator that is constructed based on the difference between short-term and long-term moving averages of a security's price.

original_glossary_extracted: Multi-factor model  A model that explains a variable in terms of the values of a set of factors.
definition_or_explanation: A model that explains a variable in terms of the values of a set of factors.

original_glossary_extracted: Multi-market indexes  Comprised of indexes from different countries, designed to represent multiple security markets.
definition_or_explanation: Comprised of indexes from different countries, designed to represent multiple security markets.

original_glossary_extracted: Multi-step format  With respect to the format of the income statement, a format that presents a subtotal for gross profit (revenue minus cost of goods sold).
definition_or_explanation: With respect to the format of the income statement, a format that presents a subtotal for gross profit (revenue minus cost of goods sold).

original_glossary_extracted: Multilateral trading facilities  See alternative trading systems.
definition_or_explanation: See alternative trading systems.

original_glossary_extracted: Multinational corporation  A company operating in more than one country or having subsidiary firms in more than one country.
definition_or_explanation: A company operating in more than one country or having subsidiary firms in more than one country.

original_glossary_extracted: Multiplication rule for probabilities  The rule that the joint probability of events A and B equals the probability of A given B times the probability of B.
definition_or_explanation: The rule that the joint probability of events A and B equals the probability of A given B times the probability of B.

original_glossary_extracted: Multiplier models  Valuation models based on share price multiples or enterprise value multiples.
definition_or_explanation: Valuation models based on share price multiples or enterprise value multiples.

original_glossary_extracted: Multivariate distribution  A probability distribution that specifies the probabilities for a group of related random variables.
definition_or_explanation: A probability distribution that specifies the probabilities for a group of related random variables.

original_glossary_extracted: Multivariate normal distribution  A probability distribution for a group of random variables that is completely defined by the means and variances of the variables plus all the correlations between pairs of the variables.
definition_or_explanation: A probability distribution for a group of random variables that is completely defined by the means and variances of the variables plus all the correlations between pairs of the variables.

original_glossary_extracted: Muni  A type of non-sovereign bond issued by a state or local government in the United States. It very often (but not always) offers income tax exemptions.
definition_or_explanation: A type of non-sovereign bond issued by a state or local government in the United States. It very often (but not always) offers income tax exemptions.

original_glossary_extracted: Municipal bonds  A type of non-sovereign bond issued by a state or local government in the United States. It very often (but not always) offers income tax exemptions.
definition_or_explanation: A type of non-sovereign bond issued by a state or local government in the United States. It very often (but not always) offers income tax exemptions.

original_glossary_extracted: Mutual fund  A professionally managed investment pool in which investors in the fund typically each have a pro-rata claim on the income and value of the fund.
definition_or_explanation: A professionally managed investment pool in which investors in the fund typically each have a pro-rata claim on the income and value of the fund.

original_glossary_extracted: Mutually exclusive projects  Mutually exclusive projects com-pete directly with each other. For example, if Projects A and B are mutually exclusive, you can choose A or B, but you cannot choose both.
definition_or_explanation: Mutually exclusive projects com-pete directly with each other. For example, if Projects A and B are mutually exclusive, you can choose A or B, but you cannot choose both.

original_glossary_extracted: n Factorial  For a positive integer n, the product of the first n positive integers; 0 factorial equals 1 by definition. n factorial is written as n!.
definition_or_explanation: For a positive integer n, the product of the first n positive integers; 0 factorial equals 1 by definition. n factorial is written as n!.

original_glossary_extracted: Narrow money  The notes and coins in circulation in an econ-omy, plus other very highly liquid deposits.
definition_or_explanation: The notes and coins in circulation in an econ-omy, plus other very highly liquid deposits.

original_glossary_extracted: Nash equilibrium  When two or more participants in a non-coop-erative game have no incentive to deviate from their respective equilibrium strategies given their opponent's strategies.
definition_or_explanation: When two or more participants in a non-coop-erative game have no incentive to deviate from their respective equilibrium strategies given their opponent's strategies.

original_glossary_extracted: National income  The income received by all factors of produc-tion used in the generation of final output. National income equals gross domestic product (or, in some countries, gross national product) minus the capital consumption allowance and a statistical discrepancy.
definition_or_explanation: The income received by all factors of produc-tion used in the generation of final output. National income equals gross domestic product (or, in some countries, gross national product) minus the capital consumption allowance and a statistical discrepancy.

original_glossary_extracted: Natural language processing  Computer programs developed to analyze and interpret human language.
definition_or_explanation: Computer programs developed to analyze and interpret human language.

original_glossary_extracted: Natural rate of unemployment  Effective unemployment rate, below which pressure emerges in labor markets.
definition_or_explanation: Effective unemployment rate, below which pressure emerges in labor markets.

original_glossary_extracted: Negative screening  An ESG implementation approach that excludes certain sectors or companies that deviate from an investor's accepted standards. Also called exclusionary screening or norms-based screening.
definition_or_explanation: An ESG implementation approach that excludes certain sectors or companies that deviate from an investor's accepted standards. Also called exclusionary screening or norms-based screening.

original_glossary_extracted: Neo-Keynesians  A group of dynamic general equilibrium models that assume slow-to-adjust prices and wages.
definition_or_explanation: A group of dynamic general equilibrium models that assume slow-to-adjust prices and wages.

original_glossary_extracted: Net book value  The remaining (undepreciated) balance of an asset's purchase cost. For liabilities, the face value of a bond minus any unamortized discount, or plus any unamortized premium.
definition_or_explanation: The remaining (undepreciated) balance of an asset's purchase cost. For liabilities, the face value of a bond minus any unamortized discount, or plus any unamortized premium.

original_glossary_extracted: Net exports  The difference between the value of a country's exports and the value of its imports (i.e., value of exports minus imports).
definition_or_explanation: The difference between the value of a country's exports and the value of its imports (i.e., value of exports minus imports).

original_glossary_extracted: Net income  The difference between revenue and expenses; what remains after subtracting all expenses (including depreciation, interest, and taxes) from revenue.
definition_or_explanation: The difference between revenue and expenses; what remains after subtracting all expenses (including depreciation, interest, and taxes) from revenue.

original_glossary_extracted: Net operating cycle  An estimate of the average time that elapses between paying suppliers for materials and col-lecting cash from the subsequent sale of goods produced.
definition_or_explanation: An estimate of the average time that elapses between paying suppliers for materials and col-lecting cash from the subsequent sale of goods produced.

original_glossary_extracted: Net present value  (NPV) The present value of an investment's cash inflows (benefits) minus the present value of its cash outflows (costs).
definition_or_explanation: The present value of an investment's cash inflows (benefits) minus the present value of its cash outflows (costs).

original_glossary_extracted: Net profit margin  An indicator of profitability, calculated as net income divided by revenue; indicates how much of each dollar of revenues is left after all costs and expenses. Also called profit margin or return on sales.
definition_or_explanation: An indicator of profitability, calculated as net income divided by revenue; indicates how much of each dollar of revenues is left after all costs and expenses. Also called profit margin or return on sales.

original_glossary_extracted: Net realisable value  Estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business less the estimated costs necessary to make the sale.
definition_or_explanation: Estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business less the estimated costs necessary to make the sale.

original_glossary_extracted: Net revenue  Revenue after adjustments (e.g., for estimated returns or for amounts unlikely to be collected).
definition_or_explanation: Revenue after adjustments (e.g., for estimated returns or for amounts unlikely to be collected).

original_glossary_extracted: Net tax rate  The tax rate net of transfer payments.
definition_or_explanation: The tax rate net of transfer payments.

original_glossary_extracted: Neural networks  Computer programs based on how our own brains learn and process information.
definition_or_explanation: Computer programs based on how our own brains learn and process information.

original_glossary_extracted: Neutral rate of interest  The rate of interest that neither spurs on nor slows down the underlying economy.
definition_or_explanation: The rate of interest that neither spurs on nor slows down the underlying economy.

original_glossary_extracted: New classical macroeconomics  An approach to macroeco-nomics that seeks the macroeconomic conclusions of individuals maximizing utility on the basis of rational expectations and companies maximizing profits.
definition_or_explanation: An approach to macroeco-nomics that seeks the macroeconomic conclusions of individuals maximizing utility on the basis of rational expectations and companies maximizing profits.

original_glossary_extracted: New Keynesians  A group of dynamic general equilibrium models that assume slow-to-adjust prices and wages.
definition_or_explanation: A group of dynamic general equilibrium models that assume slow-to-adjust prices and wages.

original_glossary_extracted: No-load fund  A mutual fund in which there is no fee for investing in the fund or for redeeming fund shares, although there is an annual fee based on a percentage of the fund's net asset value.
definition_or_explanation: A mutual fund in which there is no fee for investing in the fund or for redeeming fund shares, although there is an annual fee based on a percentage of the fund's net asset value.

original_glossary_extracted: Node  Each value on a binomial tree from which successive moves or outcomes branch.
definition_or_explanation: Each value on a binomial tree from which successive moves or outcomes branch.

original_glossary_extracted: Nominal GDP  The value of goods and services measured at current prices.
definition_or_explanation: The value of goods and services measured at current prices.

original_glossary_extracted: Nominal rate  A rate of interest based on the security's face value.
definition_or_explanation: A rate of interest based on the security's face value.

original_glossary_extracted: Nominal risk-free interest rate  The sum of the real risk-free interest rate and the inflation premium.
definition_or_explanation: The sum of the real risk-free interest rate and the inflation premium.

original_glossary_extracted: Nominal scale  A measurement scale that categorizes data but does not rank them.
definition_or_explanation: A measurement scale that categorizes data but does not rank them.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment  Effective unemployment rate, below which pressure emerges in labor markets.
key_phrase: Non accelerating inflation rate of unemployment
definition_or_explanation: Effective unemployment rate, below which pressure emerges in labor markets.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-agency RMBS  In the United States, securities issued by private entities that are not guaranteed by a federal agency or a GSE.
definition_or_explanation: In the United States, securities issued by private entities that are not guaranteed by a federal agency or a GSE.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-cumulative preference shares  Preference shares for which dividends that are not paid in the current or subse-quent periods are forfeited permanently (instead of being accrued and paid at a later date).
definition_or_explanation: Preference shares for which dividends that are not paid in the current or subse-quent periods are forfeited permanently (instead of being accrued and paid at a later date).

original_glossary_extracted: Non-current assets  Assets that are expected to benefit the company over an extended period of time (usually more than one year).
definition_or_explanation: Assets that are expected to benefit the company over an extended period of time (usually more than one year).

original_glossary_extracted: Non-current liabilities  Obligations that broadly represent a probable sacrifice of economic benefits in periods generally greater than one year in the future.
definition_or_explanation: Obligations that broadly represent a probable sacrifice of economic benefits in periods generally greater than one year in the future.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-cyclical  A company whose performance is largely inde-pendent of the business cycle.
definition_or_explanation: A company whose performance is largely inde-pendent of the business cycle.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-deliverable forwards  Cash-settled forward contracts, used predominately with respect to foreign exchange for-wards. Also called contracts for differences.
definition_or_explanation: Cash-settled forward contracts, used predominately with respect to foreign exchange for-wards. Also called contracts for differences.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-financial risks  Risks that arise from sources other than changes in the external financial markets, such as changes in accounting rules, legal environment, or tax rates.
definition_or_explanation: Risks that arise from sources other than changes in the external financial markets, such as changes in accounting rules, legal environment, or tax rates.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-participating preference shares  Preference shares that do not entitle shareholders to share in the profits of the company. Instead, shareholders are only entitled to receive a fixed dividend payment and the par value of the shares in the event of liquidation.
definition_or_explanation: Preference shares that do not entitle shareholders to share in the profits of the company. Instead, shareholders are only entitled to receive a fixed dividend payment and the par value of the shares in the event of liquidation.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-recourse loan  Loan in which the lender does not have a shortfall claim against the borrower, so the lender can look only to the property to recover the outstanding mortgage balance.
definition_or_explanation: Loan in which the lender does not have a shortfall claim against the borrower, so the lender can look only to the property to recover the outstanding mortgage balance.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-renewable resources  Finite resources that are depleted once they are consumed, such as oil and coal.
definition_or_explanation: Finite resources that are depleted once they are consumed, such as oil and coal.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-sovereign bonds  A bond issued by a government below the national level, such as a province, region, state, or city.
definition_or_explanation: A bond issued by a government below the national level, such as a province, region, state, or city.

original_glossary_extracted: Non-sovereign government bonds  A bond issued by a gov-ernment below the national level, such as a province, region, state, or city.
definition_or_explanation: A bond issued by a gov-ernment below the national level, such as a province, region, state, or city.

original_glossary_extracted: Nonconventional cash flow  In a nonconventional cash flow pattern, the initial outflow is not followed by inflows only, but the cash flows can flip from positive (inflows) to nega-tive (outflows) again (or even change signs several times).
definition_or_explanation: In a nonconventional cash flow pattern, the initial outflow is not followed by inflows only, but the cash flows can flip from positive (inflows) to nega-tive (outflows) again (or even change signs several times).

original_glossary_extracted: Nonparametric test  A test that is not concerned with a parameter, or that makes minimal assumptions about the population from which a sample comes.
definition_or_explanation: A test that is not concerned with a parameter, or that makes minimal assumptions about the population from which a sample comes.

original_glossary_extracted: Nonsystematic risk  Unique risk that is local or limited to a particular asset or industry that need not affect assets outside of that asset class.
definition_or_explanation: Unique risk that is local or limited to a particular asset or industry that need not affect assets outside of that asset class.

original_glossary_extracted: Normal distribution  A continuous, symmetric probability distribution that is completely described by its mean and its variance.
definition_or_explanation: A continuous, symmetric probability distribution that is completely described by its mean and its variance.

original_glossary_extracted: Normal goods  Goods that are consumed in greater quantities as income increases.
definition_or_explanation: Goods that are consumed in greater quantities as income increases.

original_glossary_extracted: Normal profit  The level of accounting profit needed to just cover the implicit opportunity costs ignored in accounting costs.
definition_or_explanation: The level of accounting profit needed to just cover the implicit opportunity costs ignored in accounting costs.

original_glossary_extracted: Norms-based screening  An ESG implementation approach that excludes certain sectors or companies that deviate from an investor's accepted standards. Also called negative screening or exclusionary screening.
definition_or_explanation: An ESG implementation approach that excludes certain sectors or companies that deviate from an investor's accepted standards. Also called negative screening or exclusionary screening.

original_glossary_extracted: Notching  Ratings adjustment methodology where specific issues from the same borrower may be assigned different credit ratings.
definition_or_explanation: Ratings adjustment methodology where specific issues from the same borrower may be assigned different credit ratings.

original_glossary_extracted: Note rate  See mortgage rate.
definition_or_explanation: See mortgage rate.

original_glossary_extracted: Notes payable  Amounts owed by a business to creditors as a result of borrowings that are evidenced by (short-term) loan agreements.
definition_or_explanation: Amounts owed by a business to creditors as a result of borrowings that are evidenced by (short-term) loan agreements.

original_glossary_extracted: Notice period  The length of time (typically 30 to 90 days) in advance that investors may be required to notify a fund of their intent to redeem.
definition_or_explanation: The length of time (typically 30 to 90 days) in advance that investors may be required to notify a fund of their intent to redeem.

original_glossary_extracted: Notional principal  An imputed principal amount.
definition_or_explanation: An imputed principal amount.

original_glossary_extracted: NPV rule  An investment decision rule that states that an investment should be undertaken if its NPV is positive but not undertaken if its NPV is negative.
definition_or_explanation: An investment decision rule that states that an investment should be undertaken if its NPV is positive but not undertaken if its NPV is negative.

original_glossary_extracted: Number of days of inventory  An activity ratio equal to the number of days in a period divided by the inventory ratio for the period; an indication of the number of days a com-pany ties up funds in inventory.
definition_or_explanation: An activity ratio equal to the number of days in a period divided by the inventory ratio for the period; an indication of the number of days a com-pany ties up funds in inventory.

original_glossary_extracted: Number of days of payables  An activity ratio equal to the number of days in a period divided by the payables turnover ratio for the period; an estimate of the average number of days it takes a company to pay its suppliers.
definition_or_explanation: An activity ratio equal to the number of days in a period divided by the payables turnover ratio for the period; an estimate of the average number of days it takes a company to pay its suppliers.

original_glossary_extracted: Number of days of receivables  Estimate of the average num-ber of days it takes to collect on credit accounts.
definition_or_explanation: Estimate of the average num-ber of days it takes to collect on credit accounts.

original_glossary_extracted: Objective probabilities  Probabilities that generally do not vary from person to person; includes a priori and objective probabilities.
definition_or_explanation: Probabilities that generally do not vary from person to person; includes a priori and objective probabilities.

original_glossary_extracted: Off-the-run  Seasoned government bonds are off-the-run securities; they are not the most recently issued or the most actively traded.
definition_or_explanation: Seasoned government bonds are off-the-run securities; they are not the most recently issued or the most actively traded.

original_glossary_extracted: Offer  The price at which a dealer or trader is willing to sell an asset, typically qualified by a maximum quantity (ask size).
definition_or_explanation: The price at which a dealer or trader is willing to sell an asset, typically qualified by a maximum quantity (ask size).

original_glossary_extracted: Official interest rate  An interest rate that a central bank sets and announces publicly; normally the rate at which it is willing to lend money to the commercial banks. Also called official policy rate or policy rate.
definition_or_explanation: An interest rate that a central bank sets and announces publicly; normally the rate at which it is willing to lend money to the commercial banks. Also called official policy rate or policy rate.

original_glossary_extracted: Official policy rate  An interest rate that a central bank sets and announces publicly; normally the rate at which it is willing to lend money to the commercial banks.
definition_or_explanation: An interest rate that a central bank sets and announces publicly; normally the rate at which it is willing to lend money to the commercial banks.

original_glossary_extracted: Oligopoly  Market structure with a relatively small number of firms supplying the market.
definition_or_explanation: Market structure with a relatively small number of firms supplying the market.

original_glossary_extracted: On-the-run  The most recently issued and most actively traded sovereign securities.
definition_or_explanation: The most recently issued and most actively traded sovereign securities.

original_glossary_extracted: One-sided hypothesis test  A test in which the null hypothesis is rejected only if the evidence indicates that the population parameter is greater than (smaller than) θ0. The alternative hypothesis also has one side.
definition_or_explanation: A test in which the null hypothesis is rejected only if the evidence indicates that the population parameter is greater than (smaller than) θ0. The alternative hypothesis also has one side.

original_glossary_extracted: One-tailed hypothesis test  A test in which the null hypothesis is rejected only if the evidence indicates that the population parameter is greater than (smaller than) θ0. The alternative hypothesis also has one side.
definition_or_explanation: A test in which the null hypothesis is rejected only if the evidence indicates that the population parameter is greater than (smaller than) θ0. The alternative hypothesis also has one side.

original_glossary_extracted: Open economy  An economy that trades with other countries.
definition_or_explanation: An economy that trades with other countries.

original_glossary_extracted: Open-end fund  A mutual fund that accepts new investment money and issues additional shares at a value equal to the net asset value of the fund at the time of investment.
definition_or_explanation: A mutual fund that accepts new investment money and issues additional shares at a value equal to the net asset value of the fund at the time of investment.

original_glossary_extracted: Open interest  The number of outstanding contracts in a clearinghouse at any given time. The open interest figure changes daily as some parties open up new positions, while other parties offset their old positions.
definition_or_explanation: The number of outstanding contracts in a clearinghouse at any given time. The open interest figure changes daily as some parties open up new positions, while other parties offset their old positions.

original_glossary_extracted: Open market operations  The purchase or sale of bonds by the national central bank to implement monetary policy. The bonds traded are usually sovereign bonds issued by the national government.
definition_or_explanation: The purchase or sale of bonds by the national central bank to implement monetary policy. The bonds traded are usually sovereign bonds issued by the national government.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating activities  Activities that are part of the day-to-day business functioning of an entity, such as selling inventory and providing services.
definition_or_explanation: Activities that are part of the day-to-day business functioning of an entity, such as selling inventory and providing services.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating breakeven  The number of units produced and sold at which the company's operating profit is zero (revenues = operating costs).
definition_or_explanation: The number of units produced and sold at which the company's operating profit is zero (revenues = operating costs).

original_glossary_extracted: Operating cash flow  The net amount of cash provided from operating activities.
definition_or_explanation: The net amount of cash provided from operating activities.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating cycle  A measure of the time needed to convert raw materials into cash from a sale; it consists of the number of days of inventory and the number of days of receivables.
definition_or_explanation: A measure of the time needed to convert raw materials into cash from a sale; it consists of the number of days of inventory and the number of days of receivables.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating efficiency ratios  Ratios that measure how effi-ciently a company performs day-to-day tasks, such as the collection of receivables and management of inventory.
definition_or_explanation: Ratios that measure how effi-ciently a company performs day-to-day tasks, such as the collection of receivables and management of inventory.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating lease  An agreement allowing the lessee to use some asset for a period of time; essentially a rental.
definition_or_explanation: An agreement allowing the lessee to use some asset for a period of time; essentially a rental.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating leverage  The use of fixed costs in operations.
definition_or_explanation: The use of fixed costs in operations.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating profit  A company's profits on its usual business activities before deducting taxes. Also called operating income.
definition_or_explanation: A company's profits on its usual business activities before deducting taxes. Also called operating income.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating profit margin  A profitability ratio calculated as operating income (i.e., income before interest and taxes) divided by revenue. Also called operating margin.
definition_or_explanation: A profitability ratio calculated as operating income (i.e., income before interest and taxes) divided by revenue. Also called operating margin.

original_glossary_extracted: Operating risk  The risk attributed to the operating cost struc-ture, in particular the use of fixed costs in operations; the risk arising from the mix of fixed and variable costs; the risk that a company's operations may be severely affected by environmental, social, and governance risk factors.
definition_or_explanation: The risk attributed to the operating cost struc-ture, in particular the use of fixed costs in operations; the risk arising from the mix of fixed and variable costs; the risk that a company's operations may be severely affected by environmental, social, and governance risk factors.

original_glossary_extracted: Operational independence  A bank's ability to execute mon-etary policy and set interest rates in the way it thought would best meet the inflation target.
definition_or_explanation: A bank's ability to execute mon-etary policy and set interest rates in the way it thought would best meet the inflation target.

original_glossary_extracted: Operational risk  The risk of loss from failures in a company's systems and procedures.
definition_or_explanation: The risk of loss from failures in a company's systems and procedures.

original_glossary_extracted: Operationally efficient  Said of a market, a financial system, or an economy that has relatively low transaction costs.
definition_or_explanation: Said of a market, a financial system, or an economy that has relatively low transaction costs.

original_glossary_extracted: Opportunity cost  The value that investors forgo by choosing a particular course of action; the value of something in its best alternative use.
definition_or_explanation: The value that investors forgo by choosing a particular course of action; the value of something in its best alternative use.

original_glossary_extracted: Option  A financial instrument that gives one party the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset from or to another party at a fixed price over a specific period of time. Also referred to as contingent claim or option contract.
definition_or_explanation: A financial instrument that gives one party the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset from or to another party at a fixed price over a specific period of time. Also referred to as contingent claim or option contract.

original_glossary_extracted: Option-adjusted price  The value of the embedded option plus the flat price of the bond.
definition_or_explanation: The value of the embedded option plus the flat price of the bond.

original_glossary_extracted: Option-adjusted spread  OAS = Z-spread -Option value (in basis points per year).
definition_or_explanation: OAS = Z-spread -Option value (in basis points per year).

original_glossary_extracted: Option-adjusted yield  The required market discount rate whereby the price is adjusted for the value of the embed-ded option.
definition_or_explanation: The required market discount rate whereby the price is adjusted for the value of the embed-ded option.

original_glossary_extracted: Option contract  See option.
definition_or_explanation: See option.

original_glossary_extracted: Option premium  The amount of money a buyer pays and seller receives to engage in an option transaction.
definition_or_explanation: The amount of money a buyer pays and seller receives to engage in an option transaction.

original_glossary_extracted: Order  A specification of what instrument to trade, how much to trade, and whether to buy or sell.
